title: Canberra prepares to swelter through another hot day, fire ban extended as heatwave continues - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
Canberra prepares to swelter through another hot day, fire ban extended as heatwave continues Updated February 11, 2017 08:51:03 
The Canberra region is bracing for its second day of blistering conditions with temperatures above 40 degrees Celsius. How to save power: Turn off unnecessary residential lighting Set air conditioning temperature to 26 degrees Celsius or higher Minimise use of cooking equipment Consolidate refrigeration and turn off unnecessary fridges Avoid use of dishwashers, clothes dryers and vacuum cleaners Turn off domestic pool pumping, heating operations Avoid using TVs or computers for games Source: ACT Government 
Yesterday Canberrans faced the hottest maximum temperature of any capital city when the mercury reached 41C at about 5:20pm . 
There is no relief in sight today however, with the temperature again set to reach 41C as a heatwave sweeps the country. 
If temperatures climb beyond that it could become the city's hottest day ever â€” a record not broken since 1968 when it reached 42.2C at the airport. 
The hot conditions yesterday prompted concerns about power supplies, with large consumers including the airport, the National Capital Authority and Canberra's Data Centre asked to use generators. 
Today, as many more people are away from air-conditioned offices, power supplier Actew AGL said the need for forced outages was less likely. 
But general manager of energy networks Stephen Devlin was still urging Canberrans to do their bit to ease pressure on the grid. External Link: Interactive animation shows temperatures around Australia over the past week 
"We ask that customers continue to be vigilant and minimise their electricity consumption as much as possible while we work through this heatwave," he said. 
"The critical factor for [Saturday] is the extreme temperature combined with forecast high winds in the afternoon gusting to more than 40 kilometres per hour. 
"The safety of the community is our number one priority, so if winds result in damage to powerlines or cause trees to bring down powerlines, please stay well clear and report it to ActewAGL." Total fire ban extended to Sunday 
Yesterday the ACT Emergency Services Agency extended the region's total fire ban until Sunday. 
Initially the total fire ban was only in place for Friday and Saturday, but until relief comes, in the form of possible showers tomorrow afternoon, fire crews said they would remain on standby. 
Most of the ACT's nature reserves will remain closed due to the fire ban, but the Tidbinbilla and Namadgi visitor centres will remain open. 
Swimming areas at the Cotter and along the Murrumbidgee River, such as Kambah Pool, Pine Island Point Hut and Uriarra Crossing, will also be open. 
Today's hot weather comes after Canberra's hottest January on record . 
Across the month, the average maximum temperature was 32.8C, an increase of 0.5C on the previous record set in 2013.
